Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Newly reduced visual acuity
Definition: Defined as decreased clarity or sharpness of vision.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Mastitis
Definition: Defined as a inflammation of the breast, with or without accompanying infection
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS ON ADMISSION: Indicate if experienced at any time from onset of this illness to the day of presentation.
Question: Other sign(s) or symptom(s)
Definition: This refers to the presence of an alternative sign or abnormality not listed above.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced this at any time from onset of this illness to presentation.

Section: ASSESSMENT
Question: DATE OF ASSESSMENT
Definition: This indicates the day of data collection and sampling (may not be the date of completion). This may be retrospective information at the time of discharge (transfer to other hospital or dead in hospital).
Completion Guideline: Enter the date. Use the format DD/MM/YYYY.

Section: ASSESSMENT
Question: Current level of care
Answer Options: 1, Outpatient | 2, Admitted to normal ward for isolation only | 3, Admitted to normal ward for clinical care | 4, High dependency |  5, Intensive care admission
Definition: Refers to the level of care on date of assessment.
Completion Guideline: Select the highest level of care on the date of assessment.
Standardized Term Code: 737492002, Outpatient care management (procedure) | 305342007, Admission to ward (procedure) | 398162007, Admission to high dependency unit (procedure) | 305351004, Admission to intensive care unit (procedure)
Metathesaurus: C4545175, Outpatient care management | C0583229, Admission to ward | C1301858, Admission to high dependency unit | C0583239, Admission to intensive care unit

Section: ASSESSMENT
Question: Lymphadenopathy
Definition: Defined as a clinical finding of abnormal enlargement of the lymph nodes.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: ASSESSMENT
Question: Specify lymphadenopathy site(s)
Answer Options: 1, Axillary (arm pits) | 2, Cervical (neck)| 3, Inguinal (groin) | 88, Other | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the location in which lymphadenopathy was identified.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option(s) corresponding to the location of lymphadenopathy.
Standardized Term Code: 127189005, Axillary lymphadenopathy  | 127086001, Cervical lymphadenopathy  | 127199000, Inguinal Lymphadenopathy

Section: ASSESSMENT
Question: Specify other lymphadenopathy site(s)
Definition: This refers to the location in which lymphadenopathy was identified.
Completion Guideline: If 'Other', write the location in which lymphadenopathy was identified.

Section: ASSESSMENT
Question: Bacterial super-infection
Definition: Defined as a physician-diagnosed secondary bacterial infection that occurs during an existing infection or immediately following an earlier infection.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient has experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: ASSESSMENT
Question: Specify bacterial super-infection.
Answer Options: 7, Deep tissue abscess | 1, Folliculitis / cellulitis | 2, Pneumonia | 3, Gastroenteritis | 4, CNS | 5, Bacteraemia | 6, Urinary tract | 88, Other
Definition: This refers to the type or location of the bacterial super-infection.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option(s) represents the type or location of the bacterial super-infection.
Standardized Term Code: 19824006, Infection of skin and/or subcutaneous tissue | 308906005, Secondary bacterial pneumonia | 274080003, Bacterial gastroenteritis| 128119004, Bacterial infection of the central nervous system | 312124009, Bacterial urinary tract infection
Metathesaurus: C0037278, Skin Infection | C0339952, Secondary bacterial pneumonia | C0558348, Bacterial gastroenteritis | C0752180, Bacterial infection of  central nervous system  |  C1096222, Urinary tract infection bacterial

Section: ASSESSMENT
Question: Specify other bacterial super-infection
Definition: This refers to the other type(s) or location(s) of the bacterial super-infection, not specified above.
Completion Guideline: If 'Other', write the type or location of the bacterial super-infection.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Enter Vital Signs data for this date?
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if you want to record vital sign data for this day of assessment. If 'Yes', for the following questions unless otherwise specified, Record the value furthest from the normal physiological range recorded between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment. Results that were rejected by the clinical team should not be included.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Highest temperature (select units)
Definition: Refers to the highest peripheral body temperature (rectal if <3 months) between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate units for temperature.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Highest temperature (C)
Definition: Refers to the highest peripheral body temperature (rectal if <3 months) in degrees Celsius (°C) between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment.
Completion Guideline: Enter the highest peripheral body temperature (°C) recorded between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Highest temperature (F)
Definition: Refers to the highest peripheral body temperature (rectal if <3 months) in degrees Fahrenheit (°F) between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment.
Completion Guideline: Enter the highest peripheral body temperature (°F) recorded between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: HR (beats/minute)
Definition: Refers to heart rate measured in beats per minute. This may be measured manually or by electronic monitoring.
Completion Guideline: Enter the heart rate measured in beats per minute. Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: RR (bpm)
Definition: Refers to respiratory rate in breaths per minute. Manual rather than electronic measurement is preferred where possible (this is achieved by counting the number of breaths for one minute, counting how many times the chest rises within this time period).  If both abnormal low and high rate observed, record the abnormally high rate.
Completion Guideline: Enter the respiratory rate measured in breaths per minute. Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment. If both abnormal low and high rate observed, record the abnormally high rate.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Systolic BP (mmHg)
Definition: This refers to the systolic blood pressure from the observation with the lowest mean arterial pressure (if mean arterial pressure has not been calculated, report the measurement with lowest systolic blood pressure).  For example, if the blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg, enter 120 in the section marked 'systolic BP'.
Completion Guideline: Enter the systolic blood pressure measured in millimetres of mercury (mmHg). Record the systolic blood pressure from the observation with the lowest mean arterial pressure (MAP) (if mean arterial pressure has not been calculated, report the measurement with lowest systolic blood pressure) that occurred between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Diastolic BP (mmHg)
Definition: This refers to the diastolic blood pressure from the observation with the lowest mean arterial pressure (if mean arterial pressure has not been calculated, report the measurement with lowest systolic blood pressure). For example, if the blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg, enter 85 in the section marked 'diastolic BP'.
Completion Guideline: Enter the diastolic blood pressure measured in millimetres of mercury (mmHg). Record the diastolic blood pressure from the observation with the lowest mean arterial pressure (MAP) (if mean arterial pressure has not been calculated, report the measurement with lowest systolic blood pressure) that occurred between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Mean arterial blood pressure (mmHg)
Definition: Mean arterial blood pressure (MAP) may be directly measured (via intra-arterial catheter) or be approximated without an invasive procedure using the following formula: diastolic pressure plus 1/3 of the pulse pressure, where pulse pressure is systolic pressure - diastolic pressure.
Completion Guideline: Enter the lowest recorded MAP that occurred between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Lowest oxygen saturation SpO2 (%)
Definition: This refers to the oxygen saturation, that may be measured by pulse oximetry or by arterial blood gas analysis. It is irrespective of ventilation or supplemental oxygen requirement.
Completion Guideline: Enter the percentage oxygen saturation. Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Supplemental oxygen at point of SpO2 measured
Answer Options: 2, Yes-nasal prongs | 3, Yes-simple mask | 4, Yes-HFNO | 5, Yes-NIV | 6, Yes-IMV / ECMO | 0, No (Room air) | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the measured fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) delivered at the time of the above, lowest SpO2 (%), recording.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the FiO2 was measured along-side the lowest oxygen saturation (SpO2) reported above.
Standardized Term Code: 261974006, Nasal prongs (physical object) | 371908008, Oxygen administration by mask (procedure) | 1259025002,  Heated and humidified high flow oxygen therapy using nasal cannula (procedure) | 428311008, Non-invasive ventilation (regime/therapy) | 233573008, Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (procedure)
Metathesaurus: C0445087, Nasal prongs | C1299377, Oxygen administration by mask | C4761117, High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy | C1997883, Noninvasive Ventilation | C0015357, Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: FiO2 at time of lowest SpO2 (select units)
Definition: FiO2 can be reported as either a fraction or a percentage. Note that 0.21 and 21% are equivalent to the FiO2 of room-air.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate units for FiO2.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: FiO2 at time of lowest SpO2 (Fraction, 0.21-1.0)
Definition: This refers to the measured fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) delivered at the time of the above, lowest SpO2 (%), recording.
Completion Guideline: Enter the FiO2 (0.21-1.0) that was measured along-side the lowest oxygen saturation (SpO2) reported above.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: FiO2 at time of lowest SpO2 (%, 21-100)
Definition: This refers to the measured fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) delivered at the time of the above, lowest SpO2 (%), recording.
Completion Guideline: Enter the FiO2 (21-100%) that was measured along-side the lowest oxygen saturation (SpO2) reported above.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: FiO2 at time of lowest SpO2 (Highest L/min)
Definition: This refers to the measured fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) delivered at the time of the above, lowest SpO2 (%), recording.
Completion Guideline: Enter the FiO2 (L/min) that was measured along-side the lowest oxygen saturation (SpO2) reported above.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Capillary refill time >2 seconds
Definition: Capillary refill time is measured by pressing on the sternum for five seconds with a finger or thumb until the underlying skin turns white and then noting the time in seconds needed for the colour to return once the pressure is released.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the capillary refill time was greater than 2 seconds at any time between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: ACVPU
Definition: Refers to the scoring system for consciousness: alert; confused (new-onset or worsening); responding to voice; responding to pain; unresponsive.
Completion Guideline: Select the single option corresponding to the least responsive condition of the patient between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment. If the patient is being sedated on the day of assessment record the value before the sedation.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Glasgow Coma Score (GCS / 15)
Definition: The Glasgow Coma Scale is a scoring system for consciousness. It is scored out of 15 and requires an assessment of responsiveness to stimulus. Glasgow Coma Score: https://www.glasgowcomascale.org/downloads/GCS-Assessment-Aid-English.pdf?v=3
Completion Guideline: Enter the lowest GCS recorded between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment. For intubated patients and patients with a non-fenestrated tracheostomy, give 1 point for the voice component and calculate the total as usual. Suffixes such as 't' for tracheostomy cannot be entered on to the database. If the patient is sedated on the day of assessment these parameters should correspond to the values observed before sedation.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale (RASS)
Definition: Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale (RASS) is a medical scale used to measure the agitation or sedation level of a person. It ranges from -5 to +4, where 0 refers to an 'Alert and calm' patient that spontaneously pays attention.
Completion Guideline: If performed, enter the lowest value (between -5 and +4) between 00:00 to 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Section: VITAL SIGNS & ASSESSMENTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Urine flow rate (mL/24 hours)
Definition: This refers to the amount of urine the patient has produced over a 24-hour period, specifically the date of assessment. This may be measured e.g. via use of a urinary catheter or estimated.
Completion Guideline: Record the patient's urine output (in ml/24hours) over the day of assessment

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Enter signs and symptoms data for this date?
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if you want to record signs and symptoms data for this day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Fever / chills / rigors
Definition: Defined as the sensation of elevated body temperature and associated involuntary muscle twitching/contractions (chills/rigors).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Fever
Definition: Defined as the sensation of elevated body temperature without formal measurement, or a measured body temperature greater or equal to 38-degrees Celsius (38°C) or 100.4-Fahrenheit (100.4°F).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Fatigue / malaise / lethargy
Definition: Defined as the constellation of non-specific sensations: the feeling of tiredness characterised by a lack of energy or motivation; general discomfort or uneasiness; disinterestedness, listlessness, and indifference, resulting in difficulty performing simple tasks or concentrating.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Metathesaurus: C0015672, Fatigue | C0231218, Malaise  | C0023380 Lethargy

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Weight loss
Definition: Defined as the reduction in total body weight that has occurred since the onset of this illness and has been unintentional or not attributable to active dieting, exercise or dedicated medication-based weight-loss interventions. This can include patient-reported weight loss with or without objective measurements of weight.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Loss of smell / anosmia
Definition: This refers to patient reported and/or clinician-diagnosed inability of the patient to perceive odours
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Loss of taste / ageusia
Definition: This refers to patient reported and/or clinician-diagnosed loss of taste function of the tongue.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Feeling dizzy / faint
Definition: This refers to the subjective feeling of light-headedness or dizziness which may precede an episode of syncope or a sensation of unsteadiness, spinning or rocking.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during the date of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Muscle aches / myalgia
Definition: Defined as pain localised to a muscle or group of muscles.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this at any time during the date of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Joint pain / arthralgia
Definition: Defined as a sensation of marked discomfort in a joint.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Skin rash
Definition: Defined as any change in the skin which affects its appearance or texture. A rash may be localized to one part of the body or affect all the skin. Rashes may cause the skin to change colour, itch, become warm, bumpy, dry, cracked, or blistered, swell and may be painful.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Itch / pruritus
Definition: Defined as an unpleasant or intense itching sensation that produces the urge to rub or scratch the skin to obtain relief.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Change in mobility from baseline
Definition: This refers to the patient's ability to walk or mobilise.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Mobility status
Answer Options: 1, Fully ambulant | 2, Ambulant, but with some assistance | 3, Bedridden
Definition: This refers to the patient's ability to walk or mobilise.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option(s) represents patient's mobility status.
Standardized Term Code: 160680006, Fully mobile  | 427512004, Dependent for walking  | 160685001, Bed-ridden
Metathesaurus: C0231435, Mobile | CL573260, Walks with assistance | C0425251, Bed-ridden

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Cough
Definition: This refers to the presence of a cough and its characteristics. A productive cough refers to a cough accompanied by expectorated secretions (phlegm or mucus), while a non-productive cough refers to one which is not accompanied by expectorated secretions. Haemoptysis refers to the presence of blood or blood-streaked sputum from the respiratory tract.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Non-productive
Definition: A non-productive cough refers to one which is not accompanied by expectorated secretions.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Productive
Definition: A productive cough refers to a cough accompanied by expectorated secretions (phlegm or mucus)
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Hemoptysis
Definition: Haemoptysis refers to the presence of blood or blood-streaked sputum from the respiratory tract.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Palpitations
Definition: Refers to the unpleasant awareness of one's own heartbeat.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Sore throat
Definition: Defined as an unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) and perceived to originate in the throat.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Runny nose / rhinorrhoea
Definition: Defined as increased mucosal discharge of the nose.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Wheezing
Definition: Defined as a high-pitched breath sound resulting from a narrowing or obstruction of the small airway.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Shortness of breath
Definition: Defined as the uncomfortable sensation of difficult or laboured breathing that is out of proportion to the patient's level of physical activity.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Lower chest wall indrawing
Definition: Defined as a clinical sign of respiratory distress, distinguished by the abnormal inward movement of the lower chest wall during inspiration. If only the soft tissue between the ribs or above the clavicle goes in when the patient breathes, this is not lower chest wall in-drawing.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Pharyngitis / tonsillitis
Definition: This refers to pain in the throat, typically in the presence of inflammation of the throat (pharynx) and/or tonsils.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Chest pain
Definition: Defined as the unpleasant, uncomfortable or painful sensation characterised by physical discomfort localised to the chest.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Abdominal pain
Definition: Defined as an unpleasant sensation of discomfort, distress or agony in the abdominal region.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Diarrhoea
Definition: Defined as three or more loose or liquid bowel movement per day (or more frequent passage than is normal for the individual).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Constipation
Definition: This refers to irregular and infrequent or difficult evacuation of the bowels.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Vomiting
Definition: Defined as the expulsion of the stomach or small intestines through the mouth.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Persistent vomiting? (>=2/day)
Definition: Persistent vomiting is defined here as vomiting two times or more per day.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Nausea
Definition: Defined as the the unpleasant painless subjective feeling that one will imminently vomit.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Anorexia
Definition: Defined as lack or loss of appetite.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Excessive salivation
Definition: Excessive salivation or sialorrhea is a symptom best assessed by the patient.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Difficulty swallowing / dysphagia
Definition: Defined as difficulty swallowing food, liquids, or saliva.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Urinary retention
Definition: Defined as the accumulation of urine within the bladder because of the inability to urinate.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Dyspareunia
Definition: Defined as recurrent or persistent genital pain associated with sexual intercourse.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Bleeding / haemorrhage
Definition: Defined as the presence of blood in a location in which it is not physiologically normal or loss of blood from the circulation, either internally or externally. This can include epistaxis (blood from nose), gingival bleeding (blood from gums/gingiva), blood from any part of the gastrointestinal tract (gastrointestinal bleeding) or genitourinary tracts (vagina or urethra) including hematuria.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Severe bleeding / haemorrhage (requires intervention)
Definition: Defined as the severe bleeding / hemorrhage requiring medical intervention for hemostasis and/or hemodynamic support.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Specify bleeding / haemorrhage site(s)
Answer Options: 1, Skin | 7, Petechiae | 2, Nose | 3, Gums | 4, GI tract | 5, Urinary tract | 6, Vagina | 88, Other(s) | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the location of bleeding/haemorrhage site(s). Petechiae refer to small reddish or purplish spots in skin or mucous membrane as a result of localised haemorrhage. Nose bleeding refers to haemorrhage localized in the nose. Gum bleeding refers to haemorrhage affecting the gingiva. Gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding refers to haemorrhage in any segment of the gastrointestinal tract from oesophagus to rectum. Urinary tract bleeding refers to haemorrhage originating from any part of the urinary system. Vaginal bleeding refers to haemorrhage originating from vagina, unrelated to normal menstruation.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option(s) corresponding to the location of bleeding/haemorrhage site(s).
Standardized Term Code: 297968009, Bleeding skin | 271813007 Petechiae |249366005, Bleeding from nose | 86276007, Bleeding gums | 74474003, Gastrointestinal haemorrhage |34436003, blood in urine | 289530006, Bleeding from vagina
Metathesaurus: C0574741, Bleeding skin | C3808808, Epistaxis | C0017565, Gingival haemorrrhage | C0017181, Gastrointestinal haemorrhage |C3805433, haematuria | C0566961, Fresh bleeding from vagina

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Question: Jaundice
Definition: Defined as a clinical manifestation of hyperbilirubinemia, characterized by the yellowish staining of the skin, mucous membrane and/or sclera.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Headache
Definition: Defined as the experience of pain in various parts of the head, not confined to the area of distribution of any nerve.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Neck stiffness
Definition: Defined as a sensation of tightness in the neck when attempting to move it, especially after a period of inactivity. Neck stiffness often involves soreness and difficulty moving the neck, especially when trying to turn the head to the side.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Seizures / convulsions
Definition: Defined as an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterised by a transient occurrence of sudden, violent, irregular movement of the body, caused by involuntary contraction of muscles due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Altered consciousness / confusion
Definition: Defined as a level of awareness or arousal other than the patient's normal baseline.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Question: Psychological disturbance
Definition: This refers to the presence of signs or symptoms that affect an individual's thoughts, emotions, behaviours or mental well-being. The presence of psychological disturbances should be identified through a Mental Status Examination (MSE) or equivalent tool.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Definition: This refers to issues or problems that arise in the eye or its related structures. It includes complaints of a red and or itchy eye, or visual disturbance.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient experienced this between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Question: Specify ocular complaints
Answer Options: 1, Red eye(s) | 2, Itchy eye(s)| 3, Eye pain | 4, Visual disturbance | 88, Other
Definition: This refers to issues or problems that arise in the eye or its related structures. Red eye refers to any condition with dilated conjunctival or ciliary blood vessels, typical of irritation and infection. Itchy eye or ocular pruritis refers a sensation that makes a person want to scratch, in this case abnormally increased sensation of itching is in the region of the eye. Eye pain refers to an unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the eye. Visual disturbance refers to an interference to normal eyesight without necessarily affecting visual acuity.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option(s) corresponding to the ocular complaint(s).
Standardized Term Code: 1, 703630003, Red eye| 2,  74776002, Itching of eye|3, 41652007, Pain in eye| 4,  63102001, Visual distrubance|
Metathesaurus: 1, CL473769, Red eye| 2, C0022281, Itching of eye| 3, C0151827 Eye pain| 4, C0547030, Visual distrubance|

Section: SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS: Indicate if experienced between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Question: Rash distribution
Answer Options: 1, Generalised | 2, Localised around the genitals | 3, Centrifugal-more on the extremities | 4, Centripetal-more on the trunk | 88, Other distribution | 99, Unknown distribution
Definition: This refers to the pattern of distribution of the skin rash. Generalised rash refers to a widespread rash covering the entire surface of the skin. Centrifugal rash is concentrated on the distal extremities, with fewer lesions on the trunk. Centripetal rash is concentrated on the trunk, with fewer lesions on the extremities. Localised around the genitals refers to a rash concentrated around the skin on the genitals.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate pattern of distribution of the skin rash on the day of assessment.

Question: Rash morphology
Answer Options: 1, Mostly discrete lesions | 2, Semi-confluent lesions | 3, Confluent lesions | 4, Mixed morphology | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the predominant morphology of the skin rash. Discrete lesions refer to separate, distinct lesions that are not joined to one another. Confluent lesions refer to lesions that are joining or running together.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate morphology of the skin rash on the day of assessment.

Section: SKIN & MUCOSA ASSESSMENT: Record the information furthest from normal between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Rash size (skin) - widest diameter of any lesion
Definition: This refers to the size of the skin rash, recorded as the widest diameter of any lesion in centimetres (cm).
Completion Guideline: Indicate the widest diameter of any skin lesion measured in centimetres (cm) on the day of assessment.

Section: SKIN & MUCOSA ASSESSMENT: Record the information furthest from normal between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Current skin lesion status
Answer Options: 1, There are active skin lesions | 2, There are skin lesions and none of them are active (lesions in the process of healing & resolving, including scabbed lesions) | 3, All skin lesions have completely resolved (all scabs have fallen off with intact skin) | 4, No skin lesions have developed to date
Definition: This refers to the status of the skin lesions. Active skin lesions refer to macules (flat lesions), papules (raised lesions), vesicles (raised and filled with clear fluid) or pustules (raised and filed with pus, an opaque fluid) which can develop a depression in the centre (umbilication) or ulcerate. Skin lesions which are not active refer to those which have begun to crust (dry) over, in the process of healing & resolving, to form scabs (consisting of dried serum, blood, or pus). Skin lesions which have completely resolved refer to all scabs having fallen off, leaving intact underlying skin.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the most appropriate dermatological status of the skin lesions on the day of assessment.

Section: SKIN & MUCOSA ASSESSMENT: Record the information furthest from normal between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Is there residual evidence of resolved skin lesions (scar/discolouration)?
Definition: This refers to the presence of sequalae secondary to resolved or resolving skin lesions i.e. lesions that are no longer active (including scabbed lesions and lesions where all scabs have fallen off with intact skin). This can include scars or discoloration.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if there is residual evidence of resolved skin lesions on the day of assessment.

Section: SKIN & MUCOSA ASSESSMENT: Record the information furthest from normal between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Current mucosal lesion status
Answer Options: 1, There are mucosal lesions | 2, There is a history of mucosal lesions but none at present (all have resolved and mucosa is healed) | 3, No mucosal lesions have developed to date
Definition: This refers to the presence of mucosal membrane involvement. It includes the lining of the digestive tract, respiratory tract and genitourinary tract.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option that represents the extent of mucosal involvement between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: SKIN & MUCOSA ASSESSMENT: Record the information furthest from normal between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: If there are mucosal lesions: Persistent symptoms or signs of mucosal oropharyngeal lesions
Definition: This refers to the presence of mucosal membrane involvement in the oropharyngeal cavity, as evidenced by active mucosal lesions, erythema, inflammatory changes. Symptoms may include sore throat, painful ulcerations, painful or difficult swallowing.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient had symptoms of mucosal oropharyngeal lesions between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Question: Type of head, face or neck lesions
Answer Options: 1, Vesicle | 2, Pustule | 3, Ulcerated lesions | 4, Necrotising lesions | 5, Fungating lesions | 6, Haemorrhagic lesions | 88, Other
Definition: This refers to the type of skin lesions involving the head, face or neck. Vesicle refers to raised lesion and filled with clear fluid. Pustule refers to raised lesion and filed with pus, an opaque fluid. Ulcerated lesion refers to a lesion with break in the skin. Necrotising lesion refers to a lesion with necrotic (dead) tissue. Fungating lesion refers to a lesion from underlying tissues which is breaking through the skin's surface.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option that represents the type of lesions involving this area, between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Question: Type of external genitalia lesions
Answer Options: 1, Vesicle | 2, Pustule | 3, Ulcerated lesions | 4, Necrotising lesions | 5, Fungating lesions | 6, Haemorrhagic lesions | 88, Other
Definition: This refers to the type of skin lesions involving the external genitalia. Vesicle refers to raised lesion and filled with clear fluid. Pustule refers to raised lesion and filed with pus, an opaque fluid. Ulcerated lesion refers to a lesion with break in the skin. Necrotising lesion refers to a lesion with necrotic (dead) tissue. Fungating lesion refers to a lesion from underlying tissues which is breaking through the skin's surface.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option that represents the type of lesions involving this area, between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Question: Inside mouth lesion status
Answer Options: 1, Causing pain | 2, Bleeding or Discharge | 3, Ulceration
Definition: This refers to the status of mucosal lesions in the mouth (oral cavity). A lesion causing pain is associated with an unpleasant, uncomfortable or painful sensation at the site of the lesion. A lesion which is bleeding or discharging is associated with bleeding from blood vessels or serous / purulent fluid discharge at the site of the lesion. An ulcerated lesion is associated with erosion of the mucous membrane of the mouth, showing local excavation of the surface at the site of the lesion.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option that represents the type of lesions involving this area, between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Select all parenteral fluid administered
Definition: This refers to the type of parenteral or intravenous (IV) fluid is prescribed as a replacement of fluid, electrolytes, calories, vitamins, and other nutritional substances. Crystalloid fluids refers to solutions of mineral salts, including normal (0.9%) saline, Lactated Ringer's/Hartman's solution, 5% dextrose in water, 10% dextrose in water, hypotonic and hypertonic saline, among others. Albumin refers to intravenous preparations of purified human serum albumin used to replace lost albumin in patients with hypoalbuminemia, to treat hypovolemia and ascites, and as a part of some diagnostic imaging kits. Common albumin colloid solutions include Albumin 4%, 5% and 20% among others. Gelatin refers to a colloidal, isotonic, physiologically balanced, plasma volume substitute containing succinylated gelatine and electrolytes, with potential nephroprotective properties. Common gelatin parenteral fluids include Gelaspan, Gelofusine, Geloplasma, Isoplex, among others. Starches refers to an intravenous solution of hydroxyethyl starch (HES), synthetic, nonionic hydroxyethyl derivative of starch used as a plasma expander when prepared in an isotonic solution. Common starch based, synthetic colloid, parenteral fluids include hydroxyethyl starch (HES) products, among others.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option(s) corresponding to the parenteral fluid(s) administered.

Question: Blood / blood products transfusion
Definition: This refers to a transfusion of blood (whole blood or packed red blood cells) or other blood products excluding human normal immunoglobulin (e.g. albumin, granulocytes, platelets, fresh-frozen plasma (FFP), FP24, PF-24, cryoprecipitate, protein C concentrate, cryosupernatant, or a specific non-recombinant clotting factor) at any time on the date of assessment.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient received blood products or blood product transfusion any time between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment. If 'Yes' Select the product(s) below.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Select all blood products that were administered.
Answer Options: 1, Platelets | 2, Cryoprecipitate | 3, Whole blood/packed RBC | 4, Frozen fresh plasma | 5, Fibrinogen concentrate
Definition: This refers to a transfusion of blood (whole blood or packed red blood cells) or other blood products excluding human normal immunoglobulin (e.g. albumin, granulocytes, platelets, fresh-frozen plasma (FFP), FP24, PF-24, cryoprecipitate, protein C concentrate, cryosupernatant, or a specific non-recombinant clotting factor) at any time on the date of assessment. Platelets refers to the transfer of blood platelets from a donor to a recipient or reinfusion to the donor. Cryoprecipitate refers to a frozen blood product prepared from frozen plasma that contains fibrinogen (factor I), antihemophilic factor (factor VIII), factor XIII, von Willebrand factor (vWF) and fibronectin. Whole blood refers to intravenous administration of whole blood (blood that contains plasma and red blood cells) into an individual. Packed RBC refers to red blood cells from a unit of whole blood following removal of most of the plasma, leaving a unit with a haematocrit of about 60%. Fresh frozen plasma refers to the plasma that is separated from the whole blood and frozen quickly after a blood donation in order to be used for blood transfusions. Fibrinogen concentrate is a haemostatic agent used for the treatment of acute bleeding episodes in patients with congenital fibrinogen deficiency, including afibrinogenemia and hypofibrinogenemia.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option(s) corresponding to the blood product(s) that were administered.
Standardized Term Code: 1, 12719002 | Platelet transfusion (procedure) |2, 116795008 | Transfusion of cryoprecipitate (procedure) |3, 180207008 | Intravenous blood transfusion of packed cells (procedure) |4, 116861002 | Transfusion of fresh frozen plasma (procedure) | 5, 776201000 | Product containing only human fibrinogen (medicinal product) |

Question: Steroids
Definition: Corticosteroids (commonly referred to as 'steroids') refers to all types of therapeutic corticosteroid, made in the adrenal cortex (the outer part of the adrenal gland). They are also made in the laboratory. Examples include: prednisolone, prednisone, methyl-prednisolone, dexamethasone, hydrocortisone, fluticasone, betametasone. Topical preparations are not included, but inhaled preparations are included.

Question: Supplemental oxygen
Definition: This refers to any method of oxygen therapy that may be delivered via nose cannula, mask or non-invasive or invasive ventilation.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if the patient received supplemental oxygen between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Select all types of respiratory support the patient received (from 00:00 to 24:00) on the day of assessment
Answer Options: 1, Nasal prong | 2, Face mask | 3, High-flow nasal oxygen | 4, Non-invasive ventilation | 5, Invasive ventilation | 6, ECLS/ ECMO | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the mode in which the patient received supplemental oxygen on day of assessment. Non-invasive ventilation refers to the provision of ventilatory support through the patient's upper airway using a mask or similar device. Invasive ventilation means that patient has undergone tracheal intubation, for the purpose of invasive mechanical ventilation. Invasive ventilation is a method to mechanically assist or replace spontaneous breathing in patients by use of a powered device that forces oxygenated air into the lungs. The mode of intubation may be orotracheal, nasotracheal, or via a cricothyrotomy or tracheotomy. Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation (ECMO) also called to as Extracorporeal life support (ECLS) refers to application of a life support system that circulates the blood through an oxygenating system, which may consist of a pump, a membrane oxygenator, and a heat exchanger.
Completion Guideline: Select the most appropriate option(s) corresponding to the type(s) of respiratory support the patient received between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Type of non-invasive respiratory support
Definition: Non-invasive respiratory support or ventilation (NIV) refers to the provision of ventilatory support through the patient's upper airway using a mask or similar device. It includes high-flow nasal cannula, continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and bilevel positive airway pressure (BPAP).
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option corresponding to the type of NIV used between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Renal replacement therapy (RRT) or dialysis / hemofiltration
Definition: This refers to treatments that substitute for the blood-filtering function of the kidneys. It includes dialysis (hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis), hemofiltration, and hemodiafiltration. Kidney transplant may also be considered a renal replacement therapy. It may be intermittent or continuous.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if this occurred any time between 00:00 and 24:00 on day of assessment.
Standardized Term Code: 714749008, Continuous renal replacement therapy (procedure) | 895382009, Prolonged intermittent renal replacement therapy (procedure)
Metathesaurus: C3649547, Continuous Renal Replacement Therapy | C5197699, Prolonged Intermittent Renal Replacement Therapy

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Type of renal replacement therapy (RRT) or dialysis / hemofiltration
Definition: This refers to treatments that substitute for the blood-filtering function of the kidneys. It includes dialysis (hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis), hemofiltration, and hemodiafiltration. Kidney transplant may also be considered a renal replacement therapy. It may be intermittent or continuous. Intermittent refers to procedures with non-continuous blood purification (e.g., dialysis, filtration and/or perfusion) via vascular access by increasing blood flow rate. Continuous refers to procedures with continuous blood purification (e.g., dialysis, filtration or perfusion) via vascular access designed to mimic kidney function in kidney diseases
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option corresponding to the type of renal replacement therapy (RRT) or dialysis / hemofiltration
Standardized Term Code: 714749008, Continuous renal replacement therapy (procedure) | 895382009, Prolonged intermittent renal replacement therapy (procedure)
Metathesaurus: C3649547, Continuous Renal Replacement Therapy | C5197699, Prolonged Intermittent Renal Replacement Therapy

Section: TREATMENTS & INTERVENTIONS: Record all interventions given between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Any vasopressor / inotropic support
Definition: This refers to continuous use of a vasopressor or inotrope for at least one hour. A vasopressor is a pharmaceutical agent that causes vasoconstriction. Agents include norepinephrine, epinephrine, vasopressin, terlipressin and phenylephrine. An inotrope is a pharmaceutical agent that alters the force of myocardial contractility. Commonly used 'positive' inotropes include dobutamine, dopamine, milrinone and adrenaline (epinephrine).
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if this agent was used for at least one hour between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment. Indicate the amount used below.
Metathesaurus: C5396785, Vasopressor therapy | C5880944, Inotropic therapy

Section: LABORATORY RESULTS: Record the value furthest from normal range between 00:00 to 24:00 on day of assessment.
Question: Enter Laboratory Results data for this date?
Definition: This section refers only to those laboratory tests that were performed at the time that the patient stayed in the clinical facility (hospital) and collected on the date of assessment. In general, results that were rejected by the clinical team (e.g. haemolysed blood samples, contaminated microbiology results) should not be reported.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if laboratory samples were taken on the date of assessment. If no laboratory samples were taken on the date of assessment indicate 'No' and skip to the next section. In general, do not report results that have been rejected by the clinical team (e.g. haemolysed sample). Unless otherwise specified, if there are multiple measurements, please report the measure furthest from the normal physiological or laboratory range between 00:00 and 24:00 hours on day of assessment.

Question: D-Dimer (mg/L)
Definition: D-Dimer is a measure for the concentration of fibrin degradation products (FDPs) in a sample. FDPs are protein fragments produced by the enzymatic action of plasmin on fibrinogen and fibrin) and are an aid in detecting the presence and degree of intravascular coagulation and fibrinolysis (the dissolution of the fibrin in a blood clot) and in monitoring therapy for disseminated intravascular coagulation (nonlocalized clotting in the blood vessels).
Completion Guideline: Write the serum D-dimer (mg/L)

Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if a malaria diagnostic test was performed on the date of assessment. If no malaria diagnostic test was performed on the date of assessment indicate 'No' and skip to the next section. In general, do not report results that have been rejected by the clinical team.

Question: Malaria test type
Answer Options: 1, Rapid antigen test | 2, Malaria film | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the type of malaria diagnostic test performed. Rapid antigen tests are lateral flow immuno-chromatographic parasite antigen-detection tests, which rely on the capture of dye-labelled antibodies to produce a visible band in the results window. Malaria film refers to a film (smear) of blood examined using microscopy to visualise the malaria parasites in the blood of the patient.
Completion Guideline: Select the type of malaria diagnostic test performed.

Question: Ferritin (ng/mL)
Definition: Ferritin refers to an iron protein complex, containing up to 23% iron, formed by the union of ferric iron with apoferritin; it is found in the intestinal mucosa, spleen, bone marrow, reticulocytes, and liver, and regulates iron storage and transport from the intestinal lumen to plasma.
Completion Guideline: Write the serum Ferritin (ng/mL).

Section: IMAGING

Definition: This refers to any chest x-ray that was performed at the time the patient stayed in the clinical facility (hospital) and collected on the date of assessment. Chest x-ray refers to radiological visualization of the chest and organs of the thoracic cavity; not restricted to visualization of the lungs, using x-rays.

Section: IMAGING
Question: Chest X-ray performed
Definition: This refers to any chest x-ray that was performed at the time the patient stayed in the clinical facility (hospital) and collected on the date of assessment. Chest x-ray refers to radiological visualization of the chest and organs of the thoracic cavity; not restricted to visualization of the lungs, using x-rays.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if any chest x-ray was performed at the time the patient stayed in the clinical facility (hospital) and collected on the date of assessment.

Section: IMAGING

Completion Guideline: Write the date in which the chest x-ray was performed (use the format DD/MM/YYYY).

Section: IMAGING
Question: Chest X-ray findings associated with this illness.
Answer Options: 1, Normal or no acute change | 5, Abnormal or acute change | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to chest X-ray findings associated with this illness.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option corresponding to the chest X-ray findings associated with this illness.
Standardized Term Code: 1290959000, Plain X-ray of chest normal (finding) | 1290960005, Plain X-ray of chest abnormal (finding)
Metathesaurus: C0239026, Standard chest X-ray normal | C0436503, Standard chest X-ray abnormal

Section: IMAGING
Question: New infiltrates present on X-ray
Answer Options: 1, Yes, bilateral | 2, Yes, unilateral | 0, No | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to new pulmonary infiltrates present on the current chest x-ray, not visualised on previous chest radiographs of the patient. Pulmonary infiltrates result when a substance denser than air (e.g., pus, oedema, blood, surfactant, protein, or cells) is present within the lung parenchyma. Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates are present in both lungs. Unilateral pulmonary infiltrates are present in one lung only.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option corresponding to the new pulmonary infiltrates present on the current chest x-ray, not visualised on previous chest radiographs of the patient.

Section: IMAGING
Question: Infiltrates on X-ray consistent with
Answer Options: 1, Viral pneumonitis | 2, Bacterial pneumonia |3, Pulmonary oedema| 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the pathological condition with which the pulmonary infiltrates on chest x-ray may be consistent with. Viral pneumonitis characteristically produces bilateral perihilar peribronchial thickening and interstitial infiltrates which, particularly in children, due to their small-calibre airways, can result in areas of atelectasis or air trapping. Bacterial pneumonia characteristically produces focal segmental (i.e. bronchopneumonia) or lobar pulmonary opacities (i.e. lobar pneumonia). Pulmonary oedema may be characterised by cephalisation of upper lobe vessels, interstitial opacities, peribronchovascular cuffing, septal lines (Kerley B lines), airspace opacification (filling of the alveoli with fluid) which can have a perihilar or 'batwing' distribution when severe and acute; and pleural effusion.
Completion Guideline: Select all that apply.
Standardized Term Code: 75570004, Viral pneumonia (disorder) | 53084003, Bacterial pneumonia (disorder) | 19242006, Pulmonary edema (disorder)
Metathesaurus: C0032310, Pneumonia, Viral | C0004626, Pneumonia, Bacterial | C0034063, Pulmonary Oedema

Section: IMAGING
Question: Pleural effusion on X-ray
Definition: This refers to presence of fluid in the pleural cavity resulting from excessive transudation or exudation from the pleural surfaces.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes', if pleural effusion was visualised on chest x-ray.

Section: IMAGING
Question: Pleural effusion on X-ray details
Definition: This refers to the location of the pleural effusion.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the location of the pleural effusion.

Section: IMAGING
Question: Side(s) where pleural effusion identified
Definition: This refers to the side where the unilateral pleural effusion is located.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the side of the pleural effusion.

Viral pneumonitis characteristically produces bilateral perihilar peribronchial thickening and interstitial infiltrates which, particularly in children, due to their small-calibre airways, can result in areas of atelectasis or air trapping. Bacterial pneumonia characteristically produces focal segmental (i.e. bronchopneumonia) or lobar pulmonary opacities (i.e. lobar pneumonia). Pulmonary oedema may be characterised by cephalisation of upper lobe vessels, interstitial opacities, peribronchovascular cuffing, septal lines (Kerley B lines), airspace opacification (filling of the alveoli with fluid) which can have a perihilar or 'batwing' distribution when severe and acute; and pleural effusion.
Completion Guideline: Select all that apply.

Section: IMAGING
Question: Ascites
Definition: Ascites refers to a pathological increase of fluid in the peritoneal cavity.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' If ascites were identified on ultrasound on date of assessment. Indicate 'No' if there was no ascites on ultrasound on date of assessment. If the peritoneal cavity was not examined by ultrasound for ascites on date of assessment indicate 'Unknown'.

Section: IMAGING
Question: Ascites grading
Definition: Mild/small ascites (grade 1) is detectable only by ultrasonography and typically requires approximately 100mL of fluid (where normal volume is approximately 25-50mL); Moderate ascites (grade 2) implying at least 500-1000mL of peritoneal fluid and detected with physical examination; Severe ascites (grade 3) refers to the manifestation of grossly distended abdomen, may be described as tense ascites.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option corresponding to the grade of ascites detected on ultrasound imaging.

Section: IMAGING
Question: Consolidation
Definition: This refers to the presence of a radio-opaque area in the lung. The opacification is caused by fluid or solid material within the airways or lung parenchyma.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if consolidation was identified on ultrasound on date of assessment. Indicate 'No' if there was no pleural effusion(s) on ultrasound on date of assessment. Indicate 'Unknown' if the pleural space was not examined by ultrasound for pleural effusion(s) on date of assessment.

Section: IMAGING
Question: Pleural effusion
Definition: Pleural effusion refers to a pathological increase of fluid in the pleural space.
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if pleural effusion(s) was identified on ultrasound on date of assessment. Indicate 'No' if there was no pleural effusion(s) on ultrasound on date of assessment. Indicate 'Unknown' if the pleural space was not examined by ultrasound for pleural effusion(s) on date of assessment.

Section: MEDICATION: Record medications administered or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome (one form per medication).

Definition: This refers to all medications administered any time during the patient's admission in the clinical facility (hospital), including in the emergency department, and prescribed on discharge.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the type of agent, for all medications administered any time during the patient's admission in the clinical facility (hospital), including in the emergency department, and prescribed on discharge.

Section: MEDICATION: Record medications administered or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome (one form per medication).
Question: Is this medication treating the disease?
Completion Guideline: Indicate 'Yes' if this medication is being used to treat the disease caused by the pathogen of interest.

Section: MEDICATION: Record medications administered or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome (one form per medication).
Question: Antiviral
Definition: Refers to any agent(s) prescribed specifically to treat a suspected or confirmed viral infection. Examples of neuraminidase inhibitors include oseltamivir, ribavirin, acyclovir and lopinavir/ritonavir. Topical preparations are not included.
Completion Guideline: Select the antiviral agent(s) administered any time during the patient's admission in the clinical facility (hospital), including in the emergency department, and prescribed on discharge.

Section: MEDICATION: Record medications administered or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome (one form per medication).
Question: Antiviral route
Definition: This refers to the part of the body through which or into which, or the way in which, the medicinal product (drug) is introduced. Oral refers to administering by mouth. Inhaled refers to administration through the respiratory route (insufflation into the respiratory tract). IV (intravenous) refers to administering into bloodstream through injection into a vein. Topical refers to administration by application of drug preparations to the surfaces of the body, especially the skin or mucous membranes.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the route of administration for the antiviral agent.

Section: MEDICATION: Record medications administered or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome (one form per medication).
Question: Antibiotic
Definition: Antibiotics refers to any agent(s) that selectively target bacteria.
Completion Guideline: Select the antibiotic agent(s) administered any time during the patient's admission in the clinical facility (hospital), including in the emergency department, and prescribed on discharge.

Section: MEDICATION: Record medications administered or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome (one form per medication).
Question: Topical antibiotic
Answer Options: 1, Penicillins | 2, Cephalosporins | 3, Tetracyclines | 4, Aminoglycosides | 5, Macrolides | 6, Sulfonamides and trimethoprim | 7, Quinolones | 88, Other | 99, Unknown
Definition: Refers to the antibiotic class of topical antibiotic(s) administered during admission and/or prescribed on discharge.
Completion Guideline: Indicate the class of topical antibiotic(s) administered during admission and/or prescribed on discharge

Section: MEDICATION: Record medications administered or prescribed from day of presentation to day of discharge / outcome (one form per medication).
Question: Corticosteroid
Definition: Corticosteroids (commonly referred to as 'steroids') refers to all types of therapeutic corticosteroid, made in the adrenal cortex (the outer part of the adrenal gland). They are also made in the laboratory. Examples include: prednisolone, prednisone, methyl-prednisolone, dexamethasone, hydrocortisone, fluticasone, betametasone. Topical preparations are not included, but inhaled preparations are included.
Completion Guideline: Select the corticosteroid(s) administered any time during the patient's admission in the clinical facility (hospital), including in the emergency department, and prescribed on discharge.

Definition: This refers to the part of the body through which or into which, or the way in which, the medicinal product (drug) is introduced. Oral refers to administering by mouth. Question: Anticoagulation

Completion Guideline: Select the anticoagulant(s) administered any time during the patient's admission in the clinical facility (hospital), including in the emergency department, and prescribed on discharge.

Section: PATHOGEN TESTING: Results of all types of sample and pathogen testing
Question: Biospecimen type
Answer Options: 1, Nasal/NP swab | 2, Throat swab | 3, Combined nasal/NP + throat swab | 4, Sputum | 5, BAL | 6, ETA | 11, Eye swab | 12, Breast milk| 7, Lesion swab | 13, Semen | 8, Urine | 9, Faeces/rectal swab | 10, Blood | 88, Other | 99, Unknown
Definition: This refers to the type of a clinical specimen collected for pathogen testing. Nasal / Nasopharyngeal (NP) swab refers to collection biological material from within the nasal passages/nasopharynx. Throat swab refers to collection biological material from within the throat/oropharynx. Combined nasal/NP + throat swab refers to collection using both nasal / nasopharyngeal (NP) swab and throat swab. Sputum refers to material coughed up from the lungs and expectorated via the mouth. Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL) refers to washing out of the lungs with saline or mucolytic agents for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes. Endotracheal aspirate (ETA) refers to collection of specimen from endotracheal tube. Eye swab refers to collection of biological sample from the surface of the eye. Lesion swab refers to collection of biological sample from a lesion on the skin or mucous membrane. Semen refers to the secretion of male reproductive organs discharged upon ejaculation. Faeces / rectal swab refers to biological sample collected from faecal matter or from the rectum by swabbing.
Completion Guideline: Select the single most appropriate option that represents the type of clinical specimen collected for pathogen testing.
